poem:
**Island Reverie**

Tidal whispers lace the air,  
Gulls chorus in salt-sung sky.  
Hendrix hums through the briny breeze;  
Woolf pens dreams in rolling mist,  
As Tennyson treads chalky paths—  
Faint echoes of feet and thoughts.  
Here, no engines mar the hush.  
Only the earth's breath pays the toll  
For passage onto memory's isle.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Tennyson, Virginia Woolf and Jimi Hendrix – all on a car-free trip to the Isle of Wight The green tidal mudflats are noisy with gulls and lapwings as the ferry sails towards Yarmouth. Far out on sparkling water, a white sail stands out against misty downs. The Victorian poet laureate Alfred, Lord Tennyson regularly tramped over those chalky hills, declaring “the air is worth ‘sixpence a pint’”. There is no need to drive for a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
